importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the satellite launch and announcement marks a major achievement in Pakistan’s space program, signaling a new era in national technological capabilities.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The launch occurs within a broader timeframe of Pakistan’s space program development, with multiple satellite launches in 2025, indicating a rapid expansion of national space capabilities.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan has launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, marking a significant milestone in its space program.
The satellite was launched from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025, by Pakistan’s space agency SUPARCO.
Hyperspectral technology enables detection of subtle material and chemical changes on Earth, useful for monitoring crop health, water resources, and disaster damage.
The satellite is expected to enhance national capacities in precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster management.
The launch supports the development of key national initiatives, including the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), by improving geohazard risk identification.
The H1 satellite is part of a broader trend in Pakistan’s space program, which has launched three satellites in 2025 — including fully operational EO-1 and KS-1.
It may take about two months to fully calibrate the H1 satellite before it becomes fully operational.
The mission reflects Pakistan’s strategic partnership with China in peaceful space exploration and technological cooperation.

namedEntities.name: Pakistan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pakistan is the nation launching its first hyperspectral satellite, marking a breakthrough in its space capabilities and national development goals.

namedEntities.name: SUPARCO
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Space Research and Development Agency of Pakistan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: SUPARCO is the agency responsible for the launch and operation of Pakistan’s hyperspectral satellite H1, representing the state’s official space research body.

namedEntities.name: H1 satellite
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pakistan’s first hyperspectral Earth observation satellite
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite provides advanced Earth observation data that can improve agriculture, environmental monitoring, and disaster response in Pakistan.

namedEntities.name: Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A space launch facility in northwestern China
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite was launched from this center, highlighting international collaboration between Pakistan and China in space missions.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A neighboring country and space partner of Pakistan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China provided the launch site and likely technical support, reflecting the strategic space partnership between the two countries.

namedEntities.name: China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major infrastructure development initiative linking China’s Xinjiang with Pakistan’s Gwadar Port
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The hyperspectral satellite data will help assess geohazard risks along CPEC routes, improving infrastructure safety and planning.

namedEntities.name: Precision agriculture
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A farming method using data to optimize crop yields and resource use
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The satellite enables more precise monitoring of crop health and soil conditions, improving agricultural productivity in Pakistan.

namedEntities.name: Environmental monitoring
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The tracking of environmental changes such as pollution and deforestation
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hyperspectral imaging allows detailed monitoring of environmental changes, supporting sustainable development and climate resilience.

namedEntities.name: Disaster management
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The response to natural disasters like floods or earthquakes
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The satellite enables early detection of damage from natural disasters, aiding in timely and effective response efforts.

namedEntities.name: Urban planning
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The design and development of cities and infrastructure
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Satellite data supports better decision-making in land use and urban development across Pakistan.

namedEntities.name: EO-1 and KS-1
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Two other satellites launched by Pakistan in 2025
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: These satellites are fully operational, indicating that Pakistan’s space program is rapidly expanding and progressing with multiple active missions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025, through its space agency SUPARCO. This marks a major milestone in Pakistan’s space ambitions, with the satellite expected to enhance national capabilities in precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster management. The technology allows for detailed detection of material changes on Earth, such as crop health and water resources. The mission supports key national goals, including those of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), by enabling geohazard risk identification. It is part of a broader trend in Pakistan’s space program, which has launched three satellites in 2025, with two (EO-1 and KS-1) already operational. Full functionality of H1 is expected after about two months of calibration, underscoring both national technological advancement and deepening strategic ties with China.
title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
